premise_source_doc_sentence: Steven Paul Jobs  (  -LSB- ˈdʒɒbz -RSB- February 24 , 1955 -- October 5 , 2011  )  was an American entrepreneur , businessman , inventor , and industrial designer .

premise_source_doc_sentence: He was the co-founder , chairman , and chief executive officer  (  CEO  )  of Apple Inc. ; CEO and majority shareholder of Pixar ; a member of The Walt Disney Company 's board of directors following its acquisition of Pixar ; and founder , chairman , and CEO of NeXT .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Jobs and Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak are widely recognized as pioneers of the microcomputer revolution of the 1970s and 1980s .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Jobs was born in San Francisco to Syrian parents who had to put him up for adoption at birth ; he was raised in the San Francisco Bay Area during the 1960s .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Jobs briefly attended Reed College in 1972 before dropping out .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: He then decided to travel through India in 1974 seeking enlightenment and studying Zen Buddhism .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Jobs 's declassified FBI report stated that an acquaintance knew that Jobs had used the illegal drugs marijuana and LSD while he was in college .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Jobs once told a reporter that taking LSD was `` one of the two or three most important things '' he did in his life .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Jobs and Wozniak co-founded Apple in 1976 to sell Wozniak 's Apple I personal computer .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: The visionaries gained fame and wealth a year later for the Apple II , one of the first highly successful mass-produced personal computers .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: In 1979 , after a tour of PARC , Jobs saw the commercial potential of the Xerox Alto , which was mouse-driven and had a graphical user interface  (  GUI  )  .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: This led to development of the unsuccessful Apple Lisa in 1983 , followed by the breakthrough Macintosh in 1984 .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: In addition to being the first mass-produced computer with a GUI , the Macintosh introduced the sudden rise of the desktop publishing industry in 1985 with the addition of the Apple LaserWriter , the first laser printer to feature vector graphics .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Following a long power struggle , Jobs was forced out of Apple in 1985 .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: After leaving Apple , Jobs took a few of its members with him to found NeXT , a computer platform development company specializing in state-of-the-art computers for higher-education and business markets .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: In addition , Jobs helped to initiate the development of the visual effects industry when he funded the spinout of the computer graphics division of George Lucas 's Lucasfilm in 1986 .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: The new company , Pixar , would eventually produce the first fully computer-animated film , Toy Story -- an event made possible in part because of Jobs 's financial support .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: In 1997 , Apple merged with NeXT .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Within a few months of the merger , Jobs became CEO of his former company , reviving Apple at the verge of bankruptcy .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Beginning in 1997 with the `` Think different '' advertising campaign , Jobs worked closely with designer Jonathan Ive to develop a line of products that would have larger cultural ramifications : the iMac , iTunes and iTunes Store , Apple Store , iPod , iPhone , App Store , and the iPad .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Mac OS was also revamped into OS X  (  renamed `` macOS '' in 2016  )  , based on NeXT 's NeXTSTEP platform .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Jobs was diagnosed with a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor in 2003 and died on October 5 , 2011 , of respiratory arrest related to the tumor .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Its early system software was partially based on the Lisa OS , previously released by Apple for the Lisa computer in 1983 ; as part of an agreement allowing Xerox to buy shares in Apple at a favorable price , it also used concepts from the Xerox PARC Alto computer , which former Apple CEO Steve Jobs and other Macintosh team members had previewed .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Steve Jobs contracted Moritz in the early 1980s to document the development of the Macintosh for a book he was writing about Apple .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: Steve Jobs introduced the original Macintosh computer on January 24 , 1984 .

claim: The Macintosh was a disaster that Steve Jobs created.
premise_source_doc_sentence: In the Prologue to Return to the Little Kingdom : Steve Jobs , the Creation of Apple , and How It Changed the World  (  the 2009 updated reissue of The Little Kingdom  )  Moritz states that he was as incensed as Jobs was about the Time Magazine special issue : `` Steve rightly took umbrage over his portrayal and what he saw as a grotesque betrayal of confidences , while I was equally distraught by the way in which material I had arduously gathered for a book about Apple was siphoned , filtered , and poisoned with a gossipy benzene by an editor in New York whose regular task was to chronicle the wayward world of rock-and-roll music .
